questions.question: What is the most common cause of insufficient heat in a cab heating system?

options.A: Low coolant level or restricted coolant flow through heater core.
options.B: Excessive outside air temperature.

explanations.A: AC system charge does not affect heating performance.
explanations.B: Outside temperature affects heating load but doesn't cause insufficient heat output.
explanations.C: Low coolant or restricted flow prevents adequate heat transfer to cabin air.
explanations.D: Oil pressure has no relation to heating system performance.

questions.question: A heater produces warm air only at high engine RPM. What is the likely cause?

options.B: Restricted heater core or low coolant flow.

explanations.A: Thermostat affects engine temperature, not RPM-dependent heating.
explanations.B: Blower failure would prevent air delivery at all speeds.
explanations.C: Restriction requires higher RPM to generate sufficient flow for heat transfer.
explanations.D: Refrigerant is for AC system, not heating.

questions.question: What indicates a leaking heater core?

options.B: Sweet smell in cab and coolant loss without external leaks.

explanations.A: Black smoke indicates rich fuel mixture, not coolant leak.
explanations.B: Fuel economy is not primary indicator of heater core leak.
explanations.C: Heater core leaks don't cause engine noise.
explanations.D: Coolant has sweet odor; internal cab leak shows these symptoms.

questions.question: When diagnosing a heating system, what tool measures coolant flow through the heater core?

options.B: Infrared thermometer to compare inlet and outlet temperatures.

explanations.A: Compression tester is for engine cylinders.
explanations.B: Torque wrench tightens fasteners, doesn't measure flow.
explanations.C: Temperature difference between inlet/outlet indicates flow and heat transfer.
explanations.D: Tire gauge measures air pressure, not coolant flow.

questions.question: A blend door actuator fails in a heating system. What symptom occurs?

options.B: Inability to control temperature or stuck at one temperature.

explanations.A: Blend door controls hot/cold air mix; failure prevents temperature adjustment.
explanations.B: Blower motor is separate from blend door control.
explanations.C: Blend door is internal air control, doesn't cause coolant loss.
explanations.D: Blend door doesn't affect engine cooling system.

questions.question: What causes heater hoses to collapse?

options.B: Restricted radiator cap or cooling system vacuum.

explanations.A: Pressure would expand hoses, not collapse them.
explanations.B: Vacuum condition during cooldown collapses weakened or restricted hoses.
explanations.C: Temperature alone doesn't cause collapse.
explanations.D: Oil pressure is unrelated to coolant hose condition.

questions.question: An auxiliary heater fails to operate. What should be checked first?

options.B: Fuel supply, electrical power, and control switch operation.

explanations.A: Auxiliary heaters require fuel, power, and control signal to operate.
explanations.B: Tire pressure is unrelated to auxiliary heater.
explanations.C: Transmission fluid doesn't affect heater operation.
explanations.D: Brake pads are unrelated to heating system.

questions.question: What indicates a stuck-open heater control valve?

options.B: Constant heat output regardless of control position.

explanations.A: Valve stuck open allows continuous coolant flow, heat cannot be shut off.
explanations.B: Stuck open allows continuous coolant flow, providing heat.
explanations.C: Open heater valve aids cooling, doesn't cause overheating.
explanations.D: Heater valve position doesn't affect fuel pressure.

questions.subtask: G-17.02 Diagnoses ventilation and filtration systems
questions.question: What is the primary symptom of a clogged cabin air filter?

options.B: Reduced airflow from HVAC vents.

explanations.A: Clogged filter restricts airflow into cabin ventilation system.
explanations.B: Cabin filter doesn't affect engine operation.
explanations.C: Cabin air filter has no relation to transmission.
explanations.D: Air filter doesn't cause steering vibration.

questions.subtask: G-17.02 Diagnoses ventilation and filtration systems
questions.question: A ventilation system produces musty odor. What is the likely cause?

options.B: Mold or bacteria growth in evaporator or ventilation ducts.

explanations.A: Oil level doesn't cause cabin odors.
explanations.B: Moisture accumulation promotes microbial growth causing musty smell.
explanations.C: Brake wear produces burning smell, not musty odor.
explanations.D: Tire pressure is unrelated to cabin odors.

questions.subtask: G-17.02 Diagnoses ventilation and filtration systems
questions.question: The recirculation door fails to close. What symptom occurs?

options.B: Inability to recirculate cabin air; fresh air constantly enters.

explanations.A: Stuck open door allows only outside air, preventing recirculation mode.
explanations.B: Recirculation door affects cabin air, not engine cooling.
explanations.C: Air door position doesn't affect fuel system.
explanations.D: Recirculation door is separate from transmission operation.

questions.subtask: G-17.02 Diagnoses ventilation and filtration systems
questions.question: What causes excessive dust inside the cab despite closed windows?

options.B: Missing, damaged, or incorrectly installed cabin air filter.

explanations.A: Engine speed doesn't directly cause dust infiltration.
explanations.B: Filter failure allows unfiltered air and dust to enter cabin.
explanations.C: Coolant level is unrelated to dust filtration.
explanations.D: Battery charge doesn't affect air filtration.

questions.subtask: G-17.02 Diagnoses ventilation and filtration systems
questions.question: A fresh air intake duct is disconnected. What occurs?

options.B: Reduced ventilation airflow and possible dust/debris entry into blower.

explanations.A: Ventilation duct doesn't affect fuel consumption.
explanations.B: Fresh air duct serves cabin, not engine cooling.
explanations.C: Cabin ventilation doesn't affect engine operation.
explanations.D: Disconnected duct reduces airflow and allows contamination of blower system.

questions.subtask: G-17.02 Diagnoses ventilation and filtration systems
questions.question: When diagnosing poor ventilation airflow, what should be inspected?

options.B: Cabin filter condition, duct connections, and blower motor operation.

explanations.A: These components directly affect airflow delivery to cabin.
explanations.B: Transmission fluid is unrelated to ventilation.
explanations.C: Engine compression doesn't affect cabin ventilation.
explanations.D: Differential oil is separate from ventilation system.

questions.subtask: G-17.02 Diagnoses ventilation and filtration systems
questions.question: What indicates a clogged fresh air intake screen?

options.B: Reduced airflow with blower on high speed.

explanations.A: Intake screen affects cabin air, not engine operation.
explanations.B: Fresh air screen restriction doesn't impact fuel economy.
explanations.C: Cabin air intake doesn't affect hydraulic temperature.
explanations.D: Blocked screen restricts air entering ventilation system despite blower effort.

questions.question: What is the most common cause of insufficient cooling in an AC system?

options.B: Low refrigerant charge or compressor failure.

explanations.A: Engine oil level doesn't affect AC cooling.
explanations.B: Clean filter improves airflow, doesn't cause poor cooling.
explanations.C: Tire pressure is unrelated to AC performance.
explanations.D: Low refrigerant or failed compressor prevents adequate heat removal.

questions.question: An AC compressor clutch fails to engage. What should be checked first?

options.B: Refrigerant pressure, clutch coil voltage, and pressure switches.

explanations.A: Transmission fluid doesn't affect AC clutch.
explanations.B: While high coolant temp may disable AC, refrigerant and electrical are primary checks.
explanations.C: Brake fluid is separate from AC operation.
explanations.D: Low pressure, no voltage, or failed switches prevent clutch engagement.

questions.question: What indicates a restricted expansion valve or orifice tube?

options.A: High pressure on both high and low sides.
options.B: Excessive frost on evaporator and low suction pressure.

explanations.A: Restriction limits refrigerant flow, causing evaporator icing and low pressure.
explanations.B: Restriction causes low suction pressure, not high.
explanations.C: Expansion device affects AC, not directly engine temperature.
explanations.D: Exhaust noise is unrelated to AC metering device.

questions.question: An AC system shows normal pressures but produces warm air. What is the likely cause?

options.A: Blend door stuck in heat position or mode door malfunction.
options.B: Overcharged refrigerant.

explanations.A: Hydraulic system is separate from AC operation.
explanations.B: Overcharge would show abnormal pressures and reduced cooling.
explanations.C: Normal AC operation but doors directing air improperly prevents cold air delivery.
explanations.D: While low voltage affects compressor, normal pressures indicate AC is running.

questions.question: What causes an AC system to cycle on and off rapidly?

options.B: Low refrigerant charge or faulty pressure switch.

explanations.A: Proper charge provides stable operation without rapid cycling.
explanations.B: Low charge triggers pressure cutout; switch failure causes erratic cycling.
explanations.C: Oil pressure doesn't affect AC cycling.
explanations.D: Clean condenser improves performance, doesn't cause rapid cycling.

questions.question: During AC diagnosis, both high and low side pressures are high. What is indicated?

options.B: Overcharge, restricted condenser, or failed cooling fan.

explanations.A: Low charge causes low pressures on both sides.
explanations.B: High pressures on both sides indicate a problem.
explanations.C: High pressures indicate inability to reject heat, often from overcharge or poor airflow.
explanations.D: If compressor wasn't running, pressures would equalize and be moderate.

questions.question: What tool is used to detect refrigerant leaks in an AC system?

options.B: Electronic leak detector or UV dye with UV light.

explanations.A: Compression tester is for engine cylinders.
explanations.B: Ohmmeter measures electrical resistance, not refrigerant leaks.
explanations.C: Torque wrench tightens fasteners.
explanations.D: Electronic detectors sense refrigerant; UV dye glows under UV light at leak sites.

questions.question: An evaporator shows excessive frost buildup. What causes this?

options.B: Restricted airflow across evaporator or low refrigerant charge.

explanations.A: Overcharge typically shows high pressures without excessive frost.
explanations.B: Restricted air or low charge causes evaporator temperature to drop below freezing.
explanations.C: High ambient temperature would reduce frost formation.
explanations.D: Engine speed affects compressor speed but isn't primary cause of frost.

questions.question: What is the primary cause of excessive cab noise in heavy equipment?

options.B: Missing or damaged cab insulation, worn door seals, or failed engine mounts.

explanations.A: Clean filter doesn't cause noise.
explanations.B: Damaged insulation and seals allow noise transmission; worn mounts transmit vibration.
explanations.C: Proper inflation reduces noise, doesn't cause it.
explanations.D: Fuel level doesn't significantly affect cab noise.

questions.question: Exhaust noise increases significantly after muffler work. What should be checked?

options.B: Muffler installation, gasket condition, and exhaust leaks.

explanations.A: Transmission fluid doesn't affect exhaust noise.
explanations.B: Battery terminals are unrelated to exhaust noise.
explanations.C: Improper installation or leaks allow noise to escape before suppression.
explanations.D: Coolant level doesn't affect exhaust sound level.

questions.question: What causes a rattling noise from the exhaust system?

options.B: Loose heat shields, broken hangers, or internal muffler baffles.

explanations.A: Oil condition doesn't cause exhaust rattles.
explanations.B: Tire condition is unrelated to exhaust noise.
explanations.C: Loose components vibrate and rattle against exhaust or chassis.
explanations.D: Fuel filter doesn't affect exhaust system noise.

questions.question: When diagnosing cab noise issues, what tool helps identify sound sources?

options.B: Sound level meter or acoustic camera.

explanations.A: Sound meter measures levels; acoustic camera visually maps noise sources.
explanations.B: Compression gauge is for engine cylinders.
explanations.C: Torque wrench tightens fasteners.
explanations.D: Feeler gauge measures clearances.

questions.question: Cab windows whistle at highway speeds. What is the likely cause?

options.B: Damaged or missing window seals allowing air infiltration.

explanations.A: Coolant level doesn't cause window noise.
explanations.B: Hydraulic pressure doesn't affect window sealing.
explanations.C: Compression is internal engine characteristic, not related to window noise.
explanations.D: Compromised seals allow air to flow through gaps, creating whistle.

questions.question: What indicates failed engine mounts causing excessive noise transmission?

options.B: Increased vibration and noise in cab, especially during acceleration.

explanations.A: While mounts may affect efficiency slightly, noise is primary symptom.
explanations.B: Failed mounts allow engine vibration and noise to transfer directly to chassis and cab.
explanations.C: Failed mounts worsen ride quality and noise.
explanations.D: Oil consumption is unrelated to mount condition.

questions.question: A backup alarm operates at incorrect volume. What should be checked?

options.B: Alarm adjustment setting or failed alarm unit.

explanations.A: Tire pressure doesn't affect alarm volume.
explanations.B: Alarms often have volume adjustment; internal failure can also affect output.
explanations.C: Transmission fluid is unrelated to alarm operation.
explanations.D: While battery affects alarm power, adjustment and unit condition are primary concerns.

questions.question: What is the correct procedure for replacing a heater core?

options.A: Drain coolant, remove dash components for access, replace core, refill and bleed system.
options.B: Replace without draining coolant.

explanations.A: Coolant will spill during removal causing mess and coolant loss.
explanations.B: Proper procedure prevents coolant spills and ensures complete system refill.
explanations.C: Hot coolant creates burn hazard during service.
explanations.D: Bleeding removes air pockets that prevent proper heating and cause overheating.

questions.question: When installing heater hoses, what ensures proper connection?

options.B: Install correct size hose with proper clamps torqued to specification.

explanations.A: Wire is inadequate for coolant pressure and temperature.
explanations.B: Proper size and torqued clamps prevent leaks under pressure and temperature cycles.
explanations.C: Pressure will cause leaks without proper clamping.
explanations.D: Hose must be rated for coolant temperature and pressure.

questions.question: After heater core replacement, what must be done to ensure proper operation?

options.B: Bleed air from cooling system and verify heat output and no leaks.

explanations.A: Air bleeding and verification are critical final steps.
explanations.B: Air removal ensures proper flow and heat; leak check confirms installation quality.
explanations.C: System must also be bled and heat output verified.
explanations.D: Thermostat replacement is only needed if faulty.

questions.question: What is the proper method to repair a leaking heater control valve?

options.B: Replace valve with correct type for system pressure and temperature.

explanations.A: External sealant is temporary fix that will fail under pressure.
explanations.B: Small leaks will worsen and cause coolant loss and heating problems.
explanations.C: Tightening doesn't fix internal valve leaks.
explanations.D: Valve replacement with proper specifications ensures reliable operation.

questions.question: When replacing a blend door actuator, what should be verified?

options.B: Actuator calibration, door movement, and temperature control function.

explanations.A: Calibration and functional testing ensure proper temperature control.
explanations.B: Tire pressure is unrelated to actuator installation.
explanations.C: Fuel pressure doesn't relate to blend door operation.
explanations.D: Transmission is separate from HVAC system.

questions.subtask: G-18.02 Repairs ventilation and filtration systems
questions.question: What is the correct procedure for replacing a cabin air filter?

options.A: Access filter location, remove old filter, clean housing, install new filter in correct direction.
options.B: Install filter backwards for better filtration.
options.D: Reuse old filter after shaking it.

explanations.A: Proper direction ensures airflow through filter media; clean housing prevents contamination.
explanations.B: Backwards installation prevents proper filtration and may damage filter.
explanations.C: Debris in housing will contaminate new filter.
explanations.D: Filters should be replaced at service intervals, not reused.

questions.subtask: G-18.02 Repairs ventilation and filtration systems
questions.question: When repairing ventilation ducts, what material should be used?

options.B: Proper HVAC-grade duct material or approved repair tape/sealant.

explanations.A: Standard duct tape degrades from heat and fails over time.
explanations.B: Paper products are fire hazard and will deteriorate.
explanations.C: HVAC-rated materials withstand temperature and maintain airflow integrity.
explanations.D: Plastic must be rated for temperature and not emit harmful vapors.

questions.subtask: G-18.02 Repairs ventilation and filtration systems
questions.question: After cleaning the evaporator to remove mold, what should be done?

options.B: Apply antimicrobial treatment and replace cabin filter.

explanations.A: Preventive treatment and filter change prevent immediate recurrence.
explanations.B: Antimicrobial prevents regrowth; new cabin filter removes contamination.
explanations.C: Refrigerant charge is unrelated to mold remediation.
explanations.D: Engine air filter is separate from cabin ventilation cleaning.

questions.subtask: G-18.02 Repairs ventilation and filtration systems
questions.question: What is the proper method to repair a disconnected fresh air duct?

options.A: Leave disconnected if airflow seems adequate.
options.B: Reconnect securely and seal with appropriate clamp or fastener.

explanations.A: Disconnected duct reduces efficiency and allows contamination.
explanations.B: Tape alone will fail from vibration and temperature changes.
explanations.C: Secure connection ensures proper airflow and prevents debris entry.
explanations.D: Blocking prevents necessary fresh air ventilation.

questions.question: What is the first step when replacing an AC compressor?

options.B: Recover refrigerant from system using approved equipment.

explanations.A: System must be emptied before compressor removal.
explanations.B: Cutting lines releases refrigerant illegally; use proper recovery.
explanations.C: Refrigerant recovery is legally required and prevents environmental release.
explanations.D: Compressor must be disconnected with system empty.

questions.question: After replacing AC components, what procedure is required before recharging?

options.B: Evacuate system to remove air and moisture.

explanations.A: Evacuation removes air and moisture that would damage system and reduce cooling.
explanations.B: Air and moisture must be removed first.
explanations.C: Proper evacuation and charging are essential for operation.
explanations.D: System requires full specified charge for proper operation.

questions.question: When installing a new AC compressor, what must be added?

options.A: Nothing, compressor comes ready to install.
options.B: Correct type and amount of refrigerant oil per specifications.

explanations.A: Proper oil type and quantity essential for compressor longevity.
explanations.B: Compressor requires oil for lubrication; amount must be correct.
explanations.C: Engine oil is incompatible with refrigerant system.
explanations.D: Brake fluid has no place in AC system.

questions.question: What is the proper procedure to repair a refrigerant leak at a hose connection?

options.B: Recover refrigerant, replace O-rings and fittings, evacuate and recharge.

explanations.A: Tightening can damage fittings; refrigerant must be recovered first.
explanations.B: External sealant doesn't fix AC leaks and contaminates system.
explanations.C: Proper repair includes recovery, component replacement, and system preparation.
explanations.D: All leaks must be repaired to maintain charge and prevent moisture entry.

questions.question: After AC repair, system pressures are normal but cooling is poor. What should be checked?

options.B: Blend door operation and airflow across evaporator.

explanations.A: Compression doesn't affect AC cooling directly.
explanations.B: Normal pressures indicate AC working; air delivery problem prevents cooling.
explanations.C: Transmission fluid is unrelated to AC cooling.
explanations.D: Tire pressure doesn't affect cabin cooling.

questions.question: What is the correct method to replace damaged cab insulation?

options.B: Replace with proper insulation material rated for temperature and fire resistance.

explanations.A: Proper material ensures noise reduction, thermal control, and safety.
explanations.B: Missing insulation increases noise and heat transfer.
explanations.C: Household insulation may not meet fire and temperature requirements.
explanations.D: Tape doesn't provide insulation properties.

questions.question: When replacing door seals, what ensures proper fit?

options.B: Install correct seal profile for door design and ensure complete contact.

explanations.A: Seal profile must match door design for proper sealing.
explanations.B: Excessive compression can damage seal and prevent proper function.
explanations.C: Gaps defeat purpose of seal and allow noise infiltration.
explanations.D: Proper profile and complete contact ensure noise and weather sealing.

questions.question: What is the proper procedure for replacing a muffler?

options.B: Install with proper hangers, gaskets, and verify no exhaust leaks.

explanations.A: Welding without gaskets can create stress points and future leak areas.
explanations.B: Loose mounting causes noise and potential damage.
explanations.C: Wire is inadequate for exhaust system weight and vibration.
explanations.D: Proper support, sealing, and leak testing ensure quiet, safe operation.

questions.question: When installing engine mounts, what must be verified?

options.B: Correct mount type, orientation, and torque specifications are followed.
options.C: Any mount can be used in any position.
options.D: Mounts can be installed while engine is running.

explanations.A: Mounts must be torqued to specification for proper clamping.
explanations.B: Engine must be supported and off during mount installation.
explanations.C: Mounts are position-specific with different load ratings.
explanations.D: Proper type, position, and torque ensure vibration isolation and safety.
